problem.tex: Let \[f(z)=\frac{1}{z(z-1)(z-2)}.\] Give the Laurent expansion of $f(z)$ in the annulus $\text{ann}_{1,2}(0):=\mathbb{C}\setminus\overline B_2(0)$.

solution.tex: We can use partial fractions to write $\frac{1}{z(z-1)(z-2)}$ as $\frac{a}{z}+\frac{b}{z-1}+\frac{c}{z-2}$. For completeness we do that here. Cross multiplying gives \[1=a(z-1)(z-2)+bz(z-2)+cz(z-1).\] At $z=0$ we find $a=\frac{1}{2}$, at $z=1$ we find $b=-1$, and at $z=2$ we find $c=\frac{1}{2}$. Thus \[f(z)=\frac{1}{2z}-\frac{1}{z-1}+\frac{1}{2(z-2)}.\] The region in which we are interested is outside all of the poles, so we will be factoring $z$ out of the denominator as much as we can. Thus we are more interested in expressing $f$ as \[f(z)=\frac{1}{2z}-\frac{1}{z(1-\frac{1}{z})}+\frac{1}{2z(1-\frac{2}{z})}.\] Using the geometric series formula on the second term (where $|\frac{1}{z}|<1$ because $|z|>1$) and the third (where $|\frac{2}{z}|<1$ because $|z|>2$), we have \[f(z)=\frac{1}{2z}-\frac{1}{z}\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{1}{z}\right)^n+\frac{1}{2z}\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{2}{z}\right)^n\] \[=\frac{1}{2}z^{-1}-\sum_{n=0}^\infty z^{-n-1}+\sum_{n=0}^\infty2^{n-1}z^{-n-1}=\frac{1}{2}z^{-1}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty(2^{n-2}-1)z^{-n}.\]
